Subjective: Back pain radiating down right leg. Pain in right thigh and lower leg. Pain in foot. Tingling in lower leg. Reduced strength in right leg. Dull feeling in right lower leg. Difficulty sleeping due to pain. Pain when lifting heavy objects. Pain when sitting or standing for long periods. No fever, no headache, no numbness in genital area, no difficulty urinating or defecating, no weakness in left leg. Wants to get rid of back pain, wants to sleep better, wants to return to work, worried about driving after starting pregabalin.
Objective: Vitals: not taken. Physical Exam: back pain radiating down right leg, pain in right thigh and lower leg, pain in foot, tingling in lower leg, reduced strength in right leg, dull feeling in right lower leg.
Assessment: Lumbosacral radicular syndrome, susp. HNP. No signs of cauda equina.
Plan: Physiotherapy to improve back flexibility and reduce nerve compression
Follow-up telephone appointment in 1 week to discuss pain relief progress
Contact doctor or GP out-of-hours service if symptoms worsen
Do not drive for 1 week after starting pregabalin
Do not drive if experiencing side effects from pregabalin
